head.title: Autumnal Ode.11 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 5-7.

lg.l: Now Summer with a languid look,
Already hath the plains forsook;
And Ceres,22 Roman goddess of agriculture. with a graver face,
Diffuses wealth in ev’ry place.
Chearful along the yellow land
The farmer views the reaper band;
And as he slowly stalks behind,
Or stoops the new-cut sheaves to bind,
In rustic phrase inspires the crew,
The labour jocund to pursue;
While ev’ry youth delighted moves,
To ease the ruddy maid he loves,
Whilst thus in ev’ry valley round,
Industry’s voice I hear resound,
And frequent guns with thund’ring noise,
Proclaim the jovial sportsman’s joys;
Let me across the glassy brook
Extend the line and baited hook,
And from their element, the flood,
Delude the crimson spotted brood;
Or the rude rocky cliff ascend,
O’er which the hazel bushes bend,
Where nuts embrown’d suspended high,
In tempting clusters catch the eye;
Or tracing up the hermit rill,
Ascend the summit of the hill,
Where far around on either side
The landscape stretches fair and wide.
Though lovely this autumnal scene,
Of yellow fields and vallies green;
The varigated show I find,
With melancholy clouds my mind;
To me the fading woods display—
A prospect of the year’s decay;
Where o’er the streams the branches bend,
In frequent show’rs the leaves descend,
Beauty, dejected yields the plain
To sullen winter’s dreary reign
Then come, my philosophic friend,
Thy wise advice and counsel lend;
For now the season draws us hence,
Where science doth her stores dispense.
Say, whether had we best engage,
To trace the Poets’ charming page?
Or, with sage Plato,33 Greek philosopher. seek to scan
Whence flows th’ immortal part of man?
Or with the mighty Newton soar,44 Isaac Newton (1642-1726), leading eighteenth-century British scientist.
Thy wonders, Nature, to explore?
What e’er the task to which we bend,
May virtue all our steps attend,
That, when life’s fleeting summer’s gone,
The harvest may be all our own.
